results.headline: Robbed of Youth, and Saddled With Guilt
results.summary_short: “The Life Before Her Eyes” plays an irritating game of narrative hide-and-seek, continually doubling back on itself to revisit the trauma from which all else evolves.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Life Before Her Eyes

results.headline: One More Time, Everybody Is Kung Fu Fighting
results.summary_short: “Forbidden Kingdom” is a faithful and disarmingly earnest attempt to honor some venerable and popular Chinese cinematic traditions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forbidden Kingdom

results.headline: A Deeply Spiritual Life
results.summary_short: A hair’s breadth from hagiography, Scott Hicks’s “Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts” is much like its subject: affable, quotable and emotionally guarded in the extreme.
results.display_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts

results.headline: There’s Just No Getting Away From an Old Flame, Even in Hawaii
results.summary_short: “Forgetting Sarah Marshall” does not entirely play by the established conventions of its genre.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forgetting Sarah Marshall

results.headline: Trying to Get a Glimpse Inside the Sport of Kings
results.summary_short: There are a lot of horses but absolutely no sense in “The First Saturday in May,” a glib, lazy documentary about six trainers on the road to the 2006 Kentucky Derby.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The First Saturday in May

results.headline: Resentment Over Darwin Evolves Into a Documentary
results.summary_short: One of the sleaziest documentaries to arrive in a very long time, “Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed” is a conspiracy-theory rant masquerading as investigative inquiry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed

results.headline: Music, Corsages and a Killer
results.summary_short: For a film about erotomania, “Prom Night” is a curiously flaccid affair.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prom Night

results.headline: Professor as Student of His Life and Others’
results.summary_short: The curious thing about “The Visitor” is that even as it goes more or less where you think it will, it still manages to surprise you along the way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Visitor

results.headline: Freedom in Prison
results.summary_short: “The Dhamma Brothers” is a thinking-head documentary about finding answers within for those who can’t get out.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dhamma Brothers

results.headline: A Disagreeable Academic, and a Tonic Named Sarah Jessica Parker
results.summary_short: The great virtue of “Smart People” lies in its general preference for small insights over grand revelations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Smart People

results.headline: Daily Life and Its Disruption
results.summary_short: More interested in the wages of violence than in the mechanics of revenge, “The Take” is not your average gun-toting vigilante movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Take

results.headline: If You Embrace the Body, the Heart Might Follow
results.summary_short: A fearless performance by Vera Farmiga, and glowing cinematography partly camouflage the awkward storytelling of “Never Forever.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Never Forever

results.headline: The Cultural Divide, in Cosmology and Life
results.summary_short: “Dark Matter” is a movie of ideas that does an exemplary job of translating scientific speculation into layman’s language.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Matter

results.headline: Highs and Lows
results.summary_short: “Remember the Daze” is generally entertaining but also half-baked.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Remember the Daze

results.headline: Overcoming Time’s Tyranny
results.summary_short: In Marcos Siega’s “Chaos Theory,” a man tries to overcome time’s tyranny by strictly following self-imposed schedules and lists.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chaos Theory

results.headline: Making a Splash
results.summary_short: In the disheveled Australian documentary “Bra Boys,” the obsession is not lingerie but surfing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bra Boys

results.headline: Bad Cops, but Some Worse Than Others
results.summary_short: “Street Kings” is an absurd if accidentally entertaining potboiler, based on a story by James Ellroy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Street Kings

results.headline: With Man’s Disappearance, a Family Assesses Its Faith
results.summary_short: Modest to a fault, the introverted family drama “Tehilim” circles an unsolved mystery and unresolved emotions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tehilim

results.headline: Retired, Yes, but Never Too Old to Rock
results.summary_short: To observe a fluctuating group of about two dozen singers whose average age is 80 perform in the documentary “Young@Heart” is to be uplifted, if slightly unsettled.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Young@Heart

results.headline: A Wounded Soldier Turns His Fire on the War
results.summary_short: Drenched in emotion and suffused with good intentions, “Body of War” is impossible not to like, but difficult to admire.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Body of War
